entries.content: You've got to get the prospect to discover they have a problem themselves.
Ask questions around a known problem to get the prospect to realize their current process is inefficient.
entries.notes: Do this without telling them directly.

entries.content: You can't tell a prospect their current process is 'stupid' or inefficient; they will get upset. You must guide them to see it.
Asking only 'who, what, when, where, why, how' questions gathers facts, but facts alone don't sell. You need to uncover the impact.
Get prospects to realize how the facts and figures about their current situation or problem actually hurt them.
Use 'presumptive questions' where you ask assuming they know the answer or have taken a certain action, to uncover reasons or lack thereof.
Presumptive question example to uncover lack of action: 'Can I ask you a question, when you were offered the opportunity to automate this... why did you say no to it?'
Presumptive question example to uncover common issues: 'When you turn to your sales guys and you ask them why aren't you hitting target what did they say?'
Follow up on stated reasons or excuses (uncovered via presumptive questions) by asking, 'Do you believe those excuses are valid?' to isolate the root cause or objection.

focus_area: Objection Discovery: Clarifying questions, isolation, root cause
